"You weigh more when the lights are on, then when the lights are off"

No. That would be like saying "You weigh more when someone else pushes down on your shoulders when you are on a scale, then when they don't". No, your weight is the same. The force a scale would measure would increase because it would be measuring both (a) your weight - which is unchanged - and (b) the force the other person is exerting by pushing down. Your weight would remain unchanged. It's almost like saying, "You weigh more when another person stands on the scale, then when they don't". No, you weigh the same; the force the scale measures increases because, well, you know, a second person is standing on the scale.

With g remaining the same, the only way your weight would increase is if your mass increased. A person pushing down on you, or light pushing down on you, does not increase your mass. So your weight is unchanged.

PS: Now, if you have discussed how mass and energy are interchangeable, via E=mc^2, then things would be a bit different. But you didn't mention that, so you can't bring it up now.

A shadow has no weight; neither positive nor negative.

The equation for weight is: w = m *g, where w is the weight, m is the mass of the object, and g ("little g") is the local force of gravity. Near the surface of the Earth, g is about 9.8 m/s^2.

What is the mass of a shadow? 0. A shadow is not a thing; it does not have mass. Since its mass is 0, its weight is 0.

But since it isn't the object that the light shines on that gets heavier, just as I don't weigh more when I wear clothes than I do when I'm naked. The photons that land on the object add to the weight of the object, and the sum is greater than the weight of the object itself.

Some people are saying a shadow weighs nothing because it's the absence of light, but the shadows you normally see everyday are actually the result of refraction and dispersion of light, which brings photons to places where light doesn't shine directly. If there were no light, we would simply see shadows pitch black since we can't see without light. So shadowed surfaces still receive additional weight from light unless it is a total darkness scenario, like deep underground.
On the other hand, if we ask what is the weight of a shadow, we must first ask ourselves what is a shadow. And if we consider a shadow to be the obstruction of light coming directly or indirectly from a light source, pheraps we could say a shadow has negative weight in comparison to the better illuminated neighbouring surfaces. But a shadow doesn't make a surface lighter, it only doesn't make it as heavy, so this is probably a very inaccurate way to put it.

For fun, please tell me if there's a flaw in my analysis.

Imagine the weight of the pole (made of any material of your choice, light or heavy) for use in the attempt to push (press) the button that is one light year away and attempting to compress it.

A material that is 1 light year long still has mass, despite the fact it is weightless in space, would not compress, push, or move, UNLESS, the required sum of energy, is available at the speed of sound.

That amount isn't humanly possible in a human fingertip or otherwise.

There are some significant barriers including pole material properties such as material resistance, frequency loss (absorption), and astrophysical forces including gravity, solar wind and heat.

To compress, vibrate or move an object would be a significant amount - at any frequency.

so basically when you go to push on the object, it's going to feel immovable and you would be tempted to think it's a power problem, but it's just that the item you're pushing is so big it takes a long time for it to pick up momentum.  you could hit it with a great spike of energy, but it would simply break off where it was struck.  kind of like pushing a car or a heavy pallet with a pallet jack.  it doesn't take a lot of energy to get it rolling on flat ground, but it resists more the harder you press.  it also takes time to build up momentum.  i've had the free time to try pushing a several hundred pound load with just a finger.  holding constant pressure, it slowly begins to move.  there does seem to be a break point where the pressure is so weak it wont budge even over a few minutes of continuous pressing.

Hey Vsause, how come the speed of push increases as the density of the object increases?

You're not entirely correct when you say the speed of light is slower in air than in a vacuum. The speed of light is always constant. The air just causes the photons to bounce around (like a pinball machine) which increases the total displacement that occurs. That photon is always traveling at c, it's just zigzagging around, increasing its distance.

So I would argue that the correct way to word it is "the velocity of light changes depending on the medium, but the speed is always c."

This is also why light takes so long to escape the core of the sun - it is bouncing around every which way because of the density of the sun.

It seems to me that shadow weight is like a buoyancy force. As such it depends on a medium to displace (light) and the intensity of the buoyant force is dependent on the density of the medium.

Therefor this seems to me to be the same question as: "How much does a helium balloon weight?" or "Does my weight decrease in water?"

Googling questions like this led me to the answers of:
1) Buoyancy does NOT effect "weight" and hence shadow would not effect "weight" and have a weight of nothing or 0.
2) Buoyancy DOES effect "apparent weight" and hence shadow would have a negative apparent weight.

So follow up question to the board suggestion.

Completely hypothetical obviously, but suppose you have a very long titanium rod in space. At the beginning of the rod, or at point A, you began to spin the rod from point A so that the other end of the rod or point B starts to spin the in the shape of a circle. Couldn't you get the rod long enough to get point B to go faster than "c", without ever having to increase the speed at which you spin point A and only the energy required for the initial acceleration at point A since you're in space?

If this seems convoluted imagine how the hands on an analogue clock works. At the center of the clock there is a point at which all the hands are attached to the clock, it spins at a certain speed but the end of the hands depending how long they are will spin faster and faster regardless of how much faster you spin the center. One quarter turn can make the ends of the "hands" move at completely different speeds completely dependent on how long they are right?

How long would an object need to be/how fast would point A need to spin in order to reach "c"?

And of course theoretically is it possible to achieve a speed higher than "c" by making a long enough rigid object and spinning it?

Do you remember the project back in the day where you need to drop an egg at a certain height and make something to cushion the drop? I'm going to be a dick now and ruin it for everyone, sorry:
W = Mg. Weight = Mass * gravitational field strength. That is the definition of weight. No matter what's going on with any light stuff, your weight doesn't change. Saying that Chicago "weighs" 140kg more on a sunny day isn't quite right - sure, there may well be an extra (140g)N pushing down, but that's not extra weight. It's like if you G-clamp a balance to a table so it reads 30kg. The G-clamp hasn't got any heavier, it doesn't weigh more, that's a completely separate force to weight. So shadows weigh nothing, and you're not heavier with the lights on.

His explanation of the speed of light through various mediums is highly misleading.  The speed of light is constant through all mediums.  This is a fact of science.

However, when light enters a medium (versus a vacuum) it bounces around...a LOT.  But it still bounces around at the same speed of light.  It's just that it now travels a longer distance from point A to point B instead of a straight line and therefore  it takes longer to travel a straight line due to all the bouncing.  

And the bouncing varies in each medium, which is why the speed "appears" to slow down.  In reality, the light is just bouncing around a lot more in different mediums and taking longer to travel a straight line.

@pro x vids   You asked, "Solve this please... If you could stand on a rocket moving the speed of light and started walking wouldn't you break the speed of light?"

First, it's not a valid question.  The only things that can travel through space at the speed of light are massless (photons are massless).  Nothing with positive mass, like a rocket or a person, can travel through space at the speed of light. 

Second, to answer your general question, no.  Imagine you are in the rocket going .9c (90% the speed of light), in a straight line at constant speed.  You go to the front window and then shine a flashlight out ahead of the spaceship.  That light travels away from the you and the rocket at speed c, the speed of light.  So does that mean the light from the flashlight is moving at 1.9c?    Your ship is moving .9c and the light is moving at c relative to the ship, so 0.9c + 1.0c = 1.9c.  Voila!  Faster than light!  But that's not how it works.

That simple calculation uses the type of addition of velocities we are all used to, but it is only an approximation.  At the slow speeds we travel (and even a jet travels slow compared to light), the deviation from reality is so small we couldn't notice it ourselves.  But when the speeds approach that of light, simply adding velocities becomes more and more inaccurate.  We have to use a relativistic velocity formula to add velocities under those circumstances, and when using it, no sum can exceed c. 

Nothing - not even light shown out of a rocket ship traveling at ,9c - can travel through space at a speed greater than c.  No observer is any uniformly moving reference frame would measure the light from the flashlight as a speed greater than c: in fact, all observers in all uniformly moving reference frames - even if those reference frames are moving in opposite directions to one another - would measure exactly the same speed for the light coming from the flashlight ... c.

Bottom line: in a three-dimensional Euclidean space, any object can only cast a maximum of three shadows, regardless of the number and intensity of the sources of light illuminating it.

It's at this point that it becomes impossible to add any extra sources of light, from any angle, that will not either strengthen the already projected shadows or diminish their visibility; depending on where the extra light-source is placed in relation to the backdrop.

The same holds true for a sphere, which has an infinite number of sides, or any other object regardless of shape or proportions.

To better understand this rule, think of a cube and it's six sides.
Any source of light can only illuminate up to three of it's sides at once, leaving the other three to cast the object's shadow against the background.
Add two more sources of light and you can completely illuminate all the cube's sides while casting two more extra shadows against the same background, as long as the source of light does not directly illuminate the background and stays behind the cube.

Fun-fact: 
You can only cast up to three shadows at any given time.

Regardless of the number of sources of light and their relative brightness, an object possitioned in a three-dimensional Euclidean space, i.e. the space we can perceive and interact with, can not cast more than three shadows on any surface.

 0OOOO left most side of wood is moved 1m.
 O0OOO the "0" is where the molecules of wood shrink slightly.

 OOOOO All of the wood has now been pushed 1m to the right.

Well, when you put it that way, yes, but think of it this way:
If light is present, then that means it is exerting a force on you, and you have a shadow. Since the light is exerting a force on you, you weigh slightly more. Therefore, if a shadow is not present, then you weigh less, because if a shadow is not present, then that means no light is present to push on you. So the weight of the shadow is not the material weight of the shadow itself, but the amount of light the shadow displaces.

One of his claims is that a shadow has negative weight: Chicago weighs X lbs at night (when a shadow covers all of it) and weighs X + 300 lbs at noon - so the shadow subtracts 300 lbs of WEIGHT from Chicago. " but weight increased"

No, weight did not increase.   A scale measures force, not weight.  Weight is only one force of many that can affect the measure that a scale shows.  Pushing down on someone's should who is standing on a scale does not increase that person's weight - they still weigh the same, but another force is applied to the scale.

If shadows had negative weight, they would spontaneously rise.

A helium-filled balloon has positive weight, it's just less dense than air and so rises.  Something with negative weight would be less dense than even helium, and would have to rise.

Weight is not "push".

If a person weighing 150 lbs stands on a scale and it reads 150 lbs, then I push down on his shoulders and the scale reads 175 lbs, the person's weight has not changed.  The force applied to the scale has, but that's not the same as weight.

Weight is mass times the local acceleration due to gravity (little "g").  Pushing down on a person's shoulders do not change "g" nor does it increase the person's mass by 15 lbs.

Assuming 100W lamp, you're feeling a force of E-7 N, and so weigh about E-8 kg (weight) more. However, the energy coming in is enough to evaporate E-4 kg of water per second (70 degree increase + heat of fusion). 

So if one ten-thousandth of the energy input is actually evaporating the water (the rest merely heating it), you break even in weight gain over a single second; any longer and you weigh less with the light on.

In fact, here is the accurate equation according to special relativity :
         w + u 
 v =   ---------
      1+wu/c^2
Where w and u are the velocities.
Since most of the speeds we talk about are insignificant relative to c^2, 1+wu/c^2 essentially equals 1, thus 
v = (w+u)/1

So it is possible to go faster than the speed of light. But you can't start out slow and then accelerate past the speed of light. You have to start out going faster than the speed of light and stay at that constant speed. When speaking of speeds above light speed, as long as your speed is constant you're fine but once you start accelerating you actually slow down. strange how that works.

Here's another interesting fact. Nothing with mass can accelerate past the speed of light. But that only counts for an object that is accelerating. However if something starts out going faster than the speed of light without accelerating past the speed of light, then the object can move faster than the speed of light. This has actually been done in labs using high energy particles that are emitted faster than the speed of light. IE they were already going faster than light when they were created

Also a particle and a wave are the same thing. My brother was taking a photonics course in college learning about lasers. He asked his professor to explain that and he refered him to this 1000 page book, and told him to read it about 50 times and he might come close to understanding how a particle is also a wave and vice versa. Of course it wasn't relevant to the class to understand how, he just needed to know that it was. So he still doesn't understand how. He just knows it is.

Light also does have mass, and weight and mass are interchangeable. The problem the mass of photons are so minute that they're nearly unmeasurable. But it is evident that they do have mass otherwise light would not be affected by gravity, which it is. So even though you can't weigh a shadow, there is a method somewhere for calculating it's weight. Even though a shadow is from light being blocked, it's not a total absence of light, so it would weigh less than the bright light around it.

A bullet moves faster than the speed of sound. Haven't you ever seen a rifle shot from a long distance. You will see the bullet hit the target before you hear the pop of the gun going off. Same thing with light. If you see something exploding from far away. You see the dust cloud before you hear the boom. The light that lets you see the explosion reaches your eye before the sound of the explosion reaches your ear.

Gravity literally bends space and time. 
Imagine a piece of paper only supported by the edges. The middle of this paper is not supported at all, so the table which the paper rests on essentially has a big hole in the middle. If you roll a coin down the paper, it should travel in a straight line, as expected. But if you put a heavy object in the middle of the paper, it would bend where it isn't supported. Rolling a coin now would cause it's path to be deflected slightly, because of the dip.

Mass and distance are the determining factors, mass being denoted by M, and distance by d. G is the gravitational constant which remains unchanged. The force of gravity acting on you, measured in newtons or lbs of force, remains unchanged because your mass did not change. The same can be said for the "large weight" placed on your back. The "large weight" has a constant mass, and you have a constant mass, therefore each has a constant weight. You're just adding the weight together, 2+2=4 but 2=2.

Weight is Earth's (or any other object with mass) gravity acting on your mass, but apart from that you're correct. The object on your back would not add to your personal weight. The object's force applied in addition to the force of your weight applied to the scale would be greater than just your weight alone true, but your weight would remain unchanged. Gravity would not be acting on your any more than it did before. The equation for force of gravity is F=G(M1*M2/d^2).

Kelvin (K) is a unit of temperature beginning at zero. Negative degrees Kelven cannot exist because zero degrees Kelvin is absolute zero. The coldest possible temperature in the known universe. p=m*v is an equation that deals with classical/Newtonian mechanics, which photons, as massless particles are exempt from. Newtonian mechanics are sufficient when dealing with speeds not close to that of light, but when it comes to the speed of light, or close, it is incomplete. Einstein's equation which accounts for relativistic effects has to be used instead: E^2 = (P^2)*(c^2) + (m^2)*(c^4). And the energy of a photon is not determined by it's mass, but entirely by its frequency: E = hf.

Photons, which are particles that light is made up of (ie. packets of light), have zero rest mass. However, when they are moving, they possess momentum, which pushes objects. In a vacuum, the energy and momentum of a photon is related by E = pc, where E is its energy, p is the magnitude of its momentum, and c is the speed of light.

I don't know what would happen if you moved at light speed (because I am not sure if this is even possible), but I know what would happen if you moved at near light speed. Bullet would just go away from you with relative speed as expected (relative to your point of view) but for external observer bullet would be leaving gun really slowly.

Forgetting air, rotation, and maybe few other problems. You would gain energy (momentum) falling to the center. You would lose that same amount of energy going from the center to the other side.  During the trip you would be weightless (think astronauts floating, orbiting ISS) so you how you would emerge is kind of up to you.

Forget air, rotation. You do not slow down before reaching the center. Until you reach the center there is more mass puling to the center than away from.  Now your rate of accelerating would slow as you reach the center, but overall speed increases. At the center your speed would be really fast, acceleration would be 0. Past the center you begin accelerating towards the center again, until your speed is 0 and you are on the other side.

From what I picked up from the video, it's weight can be plugged into this formula:
Let the weight of the shadow, wS, be directly related to the weight of the object it's on  (Ex. Shadow on drywall, bricks, sidewalk, etc.), wO, and the size of the shadow, s, in square inches.
wS=s(.0000001wO)
This basically means the weight of the shadow is equal to 1 billionth of the weight of the object it's on times the size of the shadow, thus giving it it's weight.

The result is that even though the truck-within-the-truck is at 100km/h relative to its parent, it's actually less than 200km/h relative to the outside.

Why does a slinky fall in this manner and not rigid objects like a thirty meter long pipe? The reason why is because the information that the slinky is falling (via compression wave) travels slower in a slinky than other material. So we can percieve it in the case of the slinky and not in the case of the pipe. In the slinky, the information telling the slinky it is falling exceeds the freefall velocity at the end, you can see this in veritasium's video where there's a rotation in the slinky.

Ohh no no. This is the most common mistake high school students make when they are presented with study of electromagnetism for the first time. See, the speed of electricity is not the speed of electrons in the wire under potential difference. (If that were true, your lamp would take several minutes to light up, when switched on). It is the time taken by electric FIELD to be field to be felt by electrons at the other end of the wire, that is relevant. (Google it. It is best explained at length.)

Little annotation here: Something being shone on by light does not necessarily have a greater mass. In fact, light shining on an object doesn't even always mean that the force pushing it "downwards" (towards the greatest source of gravity in its location) is greater than it would be if there was no light shining on it.
Just think about it: shining light onto something from the center of gravity would actually push it further AWAY from it, thus making it "lighter".
(cont.) the changing energy of a photon is due to it having a different mass.

Light DOES actually have mass (depending on context light is either viewed as a wave, or as a particle (photon)). These particles do in fact have mass, which is dependent on their energy. The "colour" of light depends on the wave's wavelength. A shorter wavelength means more energy.
When viewing light as a particle, its energy is described as kinetic energy. Since kinetic energy depends on mass and movement speed (Ekin = 1/2 m * v² for constant v) and the speed of light is constant, (cont.)

I'm not entirely sure what you mean "HOW" they figured it out. The formula is essential for many things to work, and is a proven fact at this point. If you are asking about the formula itself:
M = m / ( sqrt (1 - v^2 / c^2 ). 
M = relative mass, 
m = resting mass, 
v = speed of object, 
c = speed of light. 
Now plug in c (speed of light) for v (speed of object). You now have M = m / sqrt (1-1). Which simplifies to M = m / 0. Regardless of what m (rest mass) is (other than 0), M would = ∞.

Nothing. Because a shadow is simply the absence of light, it is not effected by speed. Your eye may not be able to see it, as your shadow will be traveling at the speed of light. But theoretically, you would still cast one, however briefly.

If you view light as particles, photons, then the reason it's slower in air is because it bounces around from air molecule to molecule. For the most part yes. That is called the Doppler Effect. Sound moves at roughly 340 meters per second and if the car is going towards you at 34 meters per second the sound waves emitted by the honking horn are compressed that much more which causes the sound of the horn to be higher in pitch. When the car is moving away from you the sound waves are elongated and sound lower than normal. It's all about the frequency of the sound waves.

Interestingly, what you have just done here is recreate more or less the exact same thought experiment that Albert Einstein used to deduce that the speed of light in a vacuum is a universal constant and maximum speed. Basically, instead of the relative speed changing, at those velocities, space and time (ie the length of the ship and the time it takes to walk through it) warp to keep c constant. In fact the length is compressed to zero at c (so it becomes impossible to walk anywhere)

Let's say we built a train, capable of reaching light speed (in vacuum). Now say on this train, a child ran forward. Wouldn't they accidentally break the light speed barrier? Although matter can't travel faster than c, couldn't a geometric point? An example - imagine a pair of scissors one light year long. Although at no point can any particle of the scissors travel faster than light, the geometric intersection of the two blades (the cutting part) can travel faster than c along the length of the blade. This could work because all particles are travelling slower than c, and only a geometric point (no mass) would be traveling faster than light.

The compression wave caused by the push does indeed travel faster in a denser medium, just like sound does (they are the same thing). However, the speed of this wave can never reach c. To understand why, we need to look at what the wave actually is. The wave is particles that move and collide with each other, each particle transferring it's kinetic energy to the next particle, causing it to move instead. The particles that make up matter have mass, and objects with mass can never reach c.

Colors are a simple tag that the brain uses to identify varying types of information that it's receiving. Naw, unfortunately you would stay in the same spot. What is happening is we are all accelerated to the same speed of the earth, and because there is nothing to stop us, we keep going at the same speed as the earth and therefore don't move in relation to it. Gravity keeps us stuck to the earth, but our inertia keeps us moving along with it. However if gravity suddenly let go, we would fly off in a straight line relative to the earth rotating and end up way off in space. Hope this helps :)

It depends what you mean by "above earth".

If you're low enough in the atmosphere, and the wind isn't pushing you, the earth would slowly rotate under you.

If you're hovering in a helicopter you will stay in the same spot with respect to the earth.  Your body, and the materials in you helicopter are traveling at the the velocity of the earth's rotation.  You don't notice this because everything else you can see is moving at the same speed.  So to become stationary with respect to the sun for example, you would have to slow down by 29.78 km/s, letting the earth leave you far behind.  (Contrast escape velocity is about 11km/s)

Light travels at the same speed, regardless of the medium at which it travels through. By saying that light travels slower through air is incorrect. Light merely takes longer to pass through air because the distance it travels is longer than in a vacuum. In air, the light doesn't travel in a straight line, rather it bumps off of the particles of air as it passes by, being bounced around. And as we all know, the shortest distance between two points is a straight line.

Normally, speed is relative. So if you are on a train moving at speed X and you run forward at speed Y, then you would perceive speed Y while on observer (not on the train) would observe you moving at speed X+Y. But as is shown by the special relativity equations, the speed of light in a vacuum, c, is not relative. Two objects both moving at speed c do not see each other as motionless relative to one another, but instead still see each other as both moving at speed c.

Sound is nothing more than a compression wave knocking the atoms back and forth. In solid matter, the atoms are much closer together than in an atmosphere, so the wave is able to propagate faster.

The same thing is true for electricity, electrons don't travel as fast as you think they do because of the number of collisions each one experiences traveling down the wire in a random walk fashion. This analogy is impossible. As the car approaches the speed of light it becomes more massive, which in turn means it requires more force to continue to accelerate. This shows that slowdown is merely illusory.

No, that is not possible. If two objects A and B are moving nearly at the speed of light and A is moving with a velocity v relative to B (resp. B with u relative to C), the velocities must be combined using the formula: w = (u+v)/(1+uv/c^2). This formula proves that, although u + v > c (speed of light), an object cannot be faster than light. If you want to know how you get to that formula, wikipedia will be more helpful than me. P.S: C is a system from which we look at A and B, such as earth.

You have just stumbled upon the theory of relativity. Allow me to explain:
1) You can't go faster than light; nothing can
2) Two objects that collide or combine velocities in some fashion, like your baseball and car, called v1 and v2, do not produce a total velocity of v1 + v2
3) Instead they produce a velocity of: ((v1 + v2)/(1+(v1+v2)/c^2))
4) Let v1=c. Thus, the total velocity will be ((c + v2)/(1+(c+v2)/c^2)).
5) By canceling some c's and v2's, it is clear that this equation always returns c

Ok, never ever weigh yourself on a scale with lights on anymore. You skew the results to seem worse than they actually are. Instead, weigh yourself in absolute dark (beware of invisible radiation) and then guess what it says.
Electric scales that record this for you don't count because they'll emit some sort of electro-magnetic radiation, skewing your weight once more.
Also beware of neuron- or muscle-activity induced electromagnetism or the earth's magnetic field.

Light is composed of photons, which are balls of pure energy but have no mass. Everything else in the universe (protons, electrons, etc..) have mass, they are heavier. That is why only photons, being "weightless", can reach the speed of light.
Light is given off when electrons fall from an "excited" atomic energy level to a lesser level. The lost energy between the two states is radiated as photons. Having no mass, they pace off at the max speed possible: the speed of light.

When you look at a star you're looking back in time. Say for sake of example that a star is a million light years away. That means that the light you're seeing, the photons, left the star a million years ago and are only now hitting your eyes. You're seeing back in time when you look at a star. The only problem I have with this entire video is the use of the phrase "universal speed limit".  I don't like it when the phrase is used because it's a presumptuous misnomer being used in the physics field to emphasize that nothing can travel faster than the speed of light. There has been no actual test to prove/disprove the hypothesis that nothing can travel faster than light. All we have are stacks of untested theories. No theory, no matter how convincing, should be taken as fact w/o testing.

There are about 16 billion neurons in your cerebral cortex. The frontal lobe (used for problem solving) takes up about 1/3 third of the cerebral cortex. Each neuron has about 7000 connections. This makes about 37 trillion connections. When neurons activate, they send signals via calcium ions. Calcium has an atomic weight of about 40 amu (atomic mass units). Each connection uses about 1000 calcium ions. With this math, an idea weighs about 37 quadrillion amu, or 6.14 x 10^-8 grams.

This is where Einstein's theory of special relativity comes in. Since c is a constant for all observers, time would actually slow down for you by something like .00000001%. For example, say you're traveling at 1/2 the speed of light. Light has to travel at c for a stationary observer, which implies that light would appear to only be moving at c/2 to you. To bring the speed of light back to c, time must slow down - in this case, double - so that light appears to move at c for that medium.

According to the theory of relativity, as an object approaches the speed of light it mass increases, and for an object to go the speed of light it's mass would increase infintely.

The speed of light constitutes a universal speed limit. Einstein's theory of special relativity dictates that an object gains mass as it accelerates. The faster it goes, the more massive it becomes. The more massive it becomes, the more thrust or push it requires in order to maintain its speed. According to relativistic predictions, if an object with any mass were to achieve the speed of light, its mass would become infinite, which is impossible in its own right.

T = √(l/g)
 velocity of the pendulum at the bottom of the swing:
v = √(2gl(1-cos(a))) 
v is the velocity of the weight at the bottom of the swing
g is the acceleration due to gravity
L is the length of the wire
a is the angle from the vertical were the pendulum is released 
√(2 × 9.8 × 4.6×10^15 (1 - cos(90))) = 300266548.3 m/s
 So we could have a pendulum with a length of 4.6 quadrillion meters that breaks the speed of light.

The light slows down upon entering the denser medium and then speeds back up when leaving  the medium for a less dense medium. Now, if you are astute you may be wondering how light can "speed back up" without an input of energy. Well, it doesn't actually ever decelerate. What happens is with the more dense medium the probability of interaction increases. Each time time it interacts with the matter in the medium, the photon disappears and a new one is made.

The answer to your question is yes, light will travel at the same speed in outer space. This is due to the laws of conservation of energy and conservation of momentum. As long as an object isn't acted on by an outside force it will continue at the same speed forever. Photons are mass-less so gravity doesn't effect them. This can be observed by light passing through a denser medium such as water from air.

6:42 The reason why the bottom of the slinky doesn't fall immediately when dropped is a simple matter of center of mass. Before the slinky is dropped, the center of mass is in the middle of the slinky. When dropped, the center of mass of the slinky falls as the spring compresses. This rule applies to any falling object. Any object can be treated as if it were falling from a single point. Its center of mass.

I don't really think that's how the slinky thing works... It's a lot simpler than that. The force exerted by the top part of the slinky on the bottom part is equal (and opposite) to the force exerted by gravity. We know that because we waited for the slinky to stop moving/accelerating, and no acceleration means no total force. And there keeps being no total force on a spot until the slinky coils above whatever spot we're looking at have fallen and are no longer pulling up.

If you mean, "How fast is the change between a hand and its shadow," then no. Imagine you're in the shower blocking the droplets from hitting the floor with your hand. It's the same with a shadow, but with a shower of photons, instead of droplets.
